utterances: So, we went well, this is looking like, if it goes from ants to cockroaches to springtails, it probably covers most of the insects.
And so the big news was, we went, well, how far back, does it go?
Let's pick something that we know always gets together in big groups.
Right.
That nobody knows of an indigenous repellent that they have, like we did with the cockroaches.
And so we picked terrestrial pill bugs and wood lice, which are little guys that everyone knows because they see them under logs but…
Right.
…what they don't realize it's related to prey-fishing lobsters.
So…
(Soundbite of laughter)
And so that…
…anyway…
…that you found it in them also.
Well, at first we did their body extract to see if they repelled by…
Right.
…their own body extract because even that was it.
And of course, we got 100 percent.
And then we identified the chemical as oleic and linoleic acids…
Wow.
…the same thing that's in all other animals.
Now how far up - if you go in the opposite direction, how high up into the - can you get it to the furry animals, where they might have their own repellents, might they recognize…
Well, we're obviously…
…the stench of death, too?
(Soundbite of laughter)
…well, we're obviously interested in that.
And we've done other work with - mate selection and other aspects of mice, for example, how they can assess other individuals.
A mouse can tell if you've been irradiated, another mouse have been irradiated.
They can tell whether it's got a virus.
They can tell if it's parasitized.
They can tell how old it is.
They can tell how effective it is and it's - if it's a male, how dominant it is.
They can tell how closely related it is.
Now, obviously the chemistry there's got to be more complex.
They certainly seem to be able to learn to avoid mousetraps.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, could we now - take now - that if we know what this fatty acid is, could we now just put it in a bottle and spray it around, instead of, you know, with a can of insecticide?
Well, we've test - the other thing we did was well, let's see how risky can we get?
So if we just pick a couple of bugs that we think it might work on - and so, all my students were astonished one day when I walked in the lab with these tree branches full of caterpillars.
And they're going, what are you doing, Dave?
And I'm like, okay.
We're going to see if we can repel all these 10 caterpillars with their own body extracts.
And they've been studied for 100 years.
There's no known indigenous chemical.
They're not known to avoid their own dead.
Hmm.
So we tested them first and we got 100 percent response, branches with the caterpillar extracts on them were intact and the ones that were not treated were defoliated.
And then we did the same thing with another family of social caterpillars, we call the fall web worm.
And there are right now, you'll often see them in the trees.
And again, we got 100 percent repulsion with the body extract.
And then we tested the two different acids and we got full effect in this with both acids, as well.
Now those ones we haven't proven that the chemicals coming from them yet, but it's pretty good bet.
Do you have to use the insects' own extract?
I mean a cockroach - will it work on the caterpillar?
Well, there's two parts to that.
We've used the standard acids.
You can just buy them from Sigma and we've used the pure acids.
We get repulsion of the cockroaches, the wood lice and the caterpillars and some other stuff with those materials without anything added to them.
So it does have a general repellant value.
On the other hand, we knew that that aggregation chemical, the recognition cue was in there.
And with the wood lice, we're getting repulsion with different dosages.
So there will be a dose, we can get rid of all of them.
But if the aggregation chemical or the smell of their own dead, in other words, if they smell it is them, then we get much more effective…
Wow.
…repulsion.
So, the raw stuff works but if you add their own odor to it…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…then they go, hey, wait.
Is something dead?
And it's us.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Get out of here.
(Soundbite of laughter)
…then they - really go.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Let's get out of here.
Yeah.
So I think there is a synergistic effect.
Yeah.
All right, doctor.
Yeah, go ahead.
Oh, so anyway, we thought at first that the chemical might be overriding the aggregation chemical.
But now the theory is…
Right.
…if you're a scientist and you make it up, it's called theory.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Theory is that if the death chemical is there, it might be that the aggregation chemical then becomes a synergistic repellant.
So, we'll have to see how that works out.
All right.
We'll follow this.
This is quite interesting.
Thank you for taking time to be with us today.
Well, thank you very much.
It was fun to be here.
You're welcome.
David Rollo is an evolutionary biologist and professor in the Department of Biology at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario.
As President Trump marks one year in office, NPR is checking on ways that his private business interests have fit with his public role.
One area to consider involves his financial dealings with Russians.

Special counsel Robert Mueller has brought money laundering charges against former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort, and there are signs that Russian money laundering has become a big part of the Mueller investigation.
NPR's Jim Zarroli reports.
When Mueller assembled his team of investigators, he included several people with experience prosecuting money laundering.
Kenneth McCallion is a former federal prosecutor who has written about Trump.
They have substantial decades of experience in the area, and I don't think he would have brought them onto his team if that wasn't going to be an area that would be focused upon.
